'''Floyd Miles''' (born April 13, 1943) is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] and [[soul blues]] guitarist, singer and songwriter.  He has released four solo albums since 1992.<ref name="AMG"/>

==Life and career==
Miles was born in [[Daytona Beach]], [[Florida]], [[United States]].<ref name="Swamp">{{cite web|url=http://swampland.com/articles/view/title:floyd_miles|title=Floyd Miles|author=Michael Buffalo Smith|date=October 2004|accessdate=21 October 2012}}</ref> He was the youngest of eleven children, and left home at the age of 15.<ref name="Miles">{{cite web|url=http://www.floydmiles.com/bio.htm|title=Floyd Miles - Bio|publisher=Floydmiles.com|accessdate=October 21, 2012}}</ref>

His musical career really started when playing with the Universals, a [[soul music|soul]] band who were locally popular in the early 1960s.<ref name="AMG"/> At the time Miles was a singing drummer for the band, and he befriended both [[Gregg Allman|Gregg]] and [[Duane Allman]] who lived nearby and jammed with the band.<ref name="Swamp"/><ref name="Allman">{{cite web|url=http://jasobrecht.com/young-duane-allman-floyd-miles-interview/|title=Young Duane Allman: The Floyd Miles Interview|publisher=Jasobrecht.com|accessdate=October 21, 2012}}</ref>

After playing drums and singing with several other local outfits, Miles founded his own group who worked backing musicians such as [[Arthur Conley]], [[Erma Franklin]], [[Curtis Mayfield]], [[Eddie Floyd]] and [[Percy Sledge]]. Through his friendship of the Allman's, Miles moved on to supply guitar backing to [[Clarence Carter]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Miles"/> He later performed with the [[London Symphony Orchestra]].<ref name="Miles"/>

His debut solo album was ''Crazy Man'' (1992), which included musical assistance from Gregg Allman and [[Dickey Betts]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/crazy-man-mw0000617781/credits|title=''Crazy Man'' - Credits|publisher=Allmusic|accessdate=October 21, 2012}}</ref> ''Goin' Back to Daytona'' was released in 1994. Miles gained a higher national prominence when he played with the [[Gregg Allman Band|Gregg Allman & Friends]] ensemble on tour.<ref name="AMG"/>

His third album, ''Mountain to Climb'' (1999), was released by Beloved Records, and Miles' latest recording, ''Another Man Will'', appeared in 2002.<ref name="AMG"/> The latter was produced by [[Roy Roberts (blues artist)|Roy Roberts]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/another-man-will-mw0000570379/credits|title=''Another Man Will'' > Credits|publisher=Allmusic|accessdate=October 21, 2012}}</ref>  Miles has performed at the [[Boundary Waters Blues Festival]], and in both 1996 and 2009 at the [[Sarasota Blues Fest]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Galipault |first=Gerry |url=http://www.heraldtribune.com/article/20090521/ARTICLE/905211016/-1/NEWSSITEMAP |title=Little Feat steps up |publisher=HeraldTribune.com |accessdate=October 21, 2012}}</ref>
